00037 #define XNARCH_DEFAULT_TICK     1000000 /* ns, i.e. 1ms */
00038 #define XNARCH_HOST_TICK        (1000000000UL/HZ)
00039 
00040 #define XNARCH_THREAD_STACKSZ   4096
00041 
00042 #define xnarch_stack_size(tcb)  ((tcb)->stacksize)
00043 #define xnarch_user_task(tcb)   ((tcb)->user_task)
00044 #define xnarch_user_pid(tcb)    ((tcb)->user_task->pid)
00045 
00046 struct xnthread;
00047 struct task_struct;
00048 
00049 typedef struct xnarchtcb {      /* Per-thread arch-dependent block */
00050 
00051     /* User mode side */
00052     struct task_struct *user_task;      /* Shadowed user-space task */
00053     struct task_struct *active_task;    /* Active user-space task */
00054     struct thread_struct *tsp;  /* Pointer to the active thread struct (&ts or &user->thread). */
00055 
00056     /* Kernel mode side */
00057     struct thread_struct ts;    /* Holds kernel-based thread context. */
00058 #ifdef CONFIG_XENO_HW_FPU
00059     /* We only care for basic FPU handling in kernel-space; Altivec
00060        and SPE are not available to kernel-based nucleus threads. */
00061     rthal_fpenv_t fpuenv  __attribute__ ((aligned (16)));
00062     rthal_fpenv_t *fpup;        /* Pointer to the FPU backup area */
00063     struct task_struct *user_fpu_owner;
00064     unsigned long user_fpu_owner_prev_msr;
00065     /* Pointer the the FPU owner in userspace:
00066        - NULL for RT K threads,
00067        - last_task_used_math for Linux US threads (only current or NULL when MP)
00068        - current for RT US threads.
00069     */
00070 #define xnarch_fpu_ptr(tcb)     ((tcb)->fpup)
00071 #else /* !CONFIG_XENO_HW_FPU */
00072 #define xnarch_fpu_ptr(tcb)     NULL
00073 #endif /* CONFIG_XENO_HW_FPU */
00074 
00075     unsigned stacksize;         /* Aligned size of stack (bytes) */
00076     unsigned long *stackbase;   /* Stack space */
00077 
00078     /* Init block */
00079     struct xnthread *self;
00080     int imask;
00081     const char *name;
00082     void (*entry)(void *cookie);
00083     void *cookie;
00084 
00085 } xnarchtcb_t;
00086 
00087 typedef struct xnarch_fltinfo {
00088 
00089     unsigned exception;
00090     struct pt_regs *regs;
00091 
00092 } xnarch_fltinfo_t;
00093 
00094 #define xnarch_fault_trap(fi)   ((unsigned int)(fi)->regs->trap)
00095 #define xnarch_fault_code(fi)   ((fi)->regs->dar)
00096 #define xnarch_fault_pc(fi)     ((fi)->regs->nip)
00097 #define xnarch_fault_pc(fi)     ((fi)->regs->nip)
00098 /* FIXME: FPU faults ignored by the nanokernel on PPC. */
00099 #define xnarch_fault_fpu_p(fi)  (0)
00100 /* The following predicates are only usable over a regular Linux stack
00101    context. */
00102 #ifdef CONFIG_ADEOS_CORE
00103 #define xnarch_fault_pf_p(fi)   ((fi)->exception == ADEOS_ACCESS_TRAP)
00104 #define xnarch_fault_bp_p(fi)   ((current->ptrace & PT_PTRACED) && \
00105                                  ((fi)->exception == ADEOS_IABR_TRAP || \
00106                                   (fi)->exception == ADEOS_SSTEP_TRAP || \
00107                                   (fi)->exception == ADEOS_DEBUG_TRAP))
00108 #else /* !CONFIG_ADEOS_CORE */
00109 #define xnarch_fault_pf_p(fi)   ((fi)->exception == IPIPE_TRAP_ACCESS)
00110 #define xnarch_fault_bp_p(fi)   ((current->ptrace & PT_PTRACED) && \
00111                                  ((fi)->exception == IPIPE_TRAP_IABR || \
00112                                   (fi)->exception == IPIPE_TRAP_SSTEP || \
00113                                   (fi)->exception == IPIPE_TRAP_DEBUG))
00114 #endif /* CONFIG_ADEOS_CORE */
00115 
00116 #define xnarch_fault_notify(fi) (!xnarch_fault_bp_p(fi))

00122 static inline void *xnarch_sysalloc (u_long bytes)
00123 
00124 {
00125 #if 0   /* FIXME: likely on-demand mapping bug here */
00126     if (bytes >= 128*1024)
00127         return vmalloc(bytes);
00128 #endif
00129 
00130     return kmalloc(bytes,GFP_KERNEL);
00131 }
00132 
00133 static inline void xnarch_sysfree (void *chunk, u_long bytes)
00134 
00135 {
00136 #if 0   /* FIXME: likely on-demand mapping bug here */
00137     if (bytes >= 128*1024)
00138         vfree(chunk);
00139     else
00140 #endif
00141         kfree(chunk);
00142 }

00144 static inline void xnarch_relay_tick (void)
00145 
00146 {
00147     rthal_irq_host_pend(RTHAL_TIMER_IRQ);
00148 }

00156 static inline int xnarch_start_timer (unsigned long ns,
00157                                       void (*tickhandler)(void))
00158 {
00159     return rthal_timer_request(tickhandler,ns);

00162 static inline void xnarch_leave_root (xnarchtcb_t *rootcb)
00163 
00164 {
00165     rthal_declare_cpuid;
00166 
00167     rthal_load_cpuid();
00168 
00169     /* rthal_cpu_realtime is only tested for the current processor,
00170        and always inside a critical section. */
00171     __set_bit(cpuid,&rthal_cpu_realtime);
00172     /* Remember the preempted Linux task pointer. */
00173     rootcb->user_task = rootcb->active_task = rthal_current_host_task(cpuid);
00174     rootcb->tsp = &rootcb->user_task->thread;
00175 #ifdef CONFIG_XENO_HW_FPU
00176     rootcb->user_fpu_owner = rthal_get_fpu_owner(rootcb->user_task);
00177     /* So that xnarch_save_fpu() will operate on the right FPU area. */
00178     rootcb->fpup = (rootcb->user_fpu_owner
00179                     ? (rthal_fpenv_t *)&rootcb->user_fpu_owner->thread.fpr[0]
00180                     : NULL);
00181 #endif /* CONFIG_XENO_HW_FPU */
00182 }
00183 
00184 static inline void xnarch_enter_root (xnarchtcb_t *rootcb)
00185 {
00186     __clear_bit(xnarch_current_cpu(),&rthal_cpu_realtime);
00187 }
00188 
00189 static inline void xnarch_switch_to (xnarchtcb_t *out_tcb,
00190                                      xnarchtcb_t *in_tcb)
00191 {
00192     struct task_struct *prev = out_tcb->active_task;
00193     struct task_struct *next = in_tcb->user_task;
00194 
00195     in_tcb->active_task = next ?: prev;
00196 
00197     if (next && next != prev) /* Switch to new user-space thread? */
00198         {
00199         struct mm_struct *mm = next->active_mm;
00200 
00201         /* Switch the mm context.*/
00202 
00203 #ifdef CONFIG_ALTIVEC
00204         /* The HAL won't let us running on an ALTIVEC-enabled kernel
00205            without proper hardware, so we don't have to care for FTR
00206            fixups here -- which is fortunate, since those would not
00207            work properly in the current context. */
00208         asm volatile (
00209                       "dssall;\n"
00210 #ifndef CONFIG_POWER4
00211                       "sync;\n"
00212 #endif
00213                       : : );
00214 #endif /* CONFIG_ALTIVEC */
00215 
00216         next->thread.pgdir = mm->pgd;
00217         get_mmu_context(mm);
00218         set_context(mm->context,mm->pgd);
00219         current = prev;         /* Make sure r2 is valid. */
00220         }
00221 
00222     rthal_thread_switch(out_tcb->tsp,in_tcb->tsp);
00223 
00224     barrier();
00225 }
00226 
00227 static inline void xnarch_finalize_and_switch (xnarchtcb_t *dead_tcb,
00228                                                xnarchtcb_t *next_tcb)
00229 {
00230     xnarch_switch_to(dead_tcb,next_tcb);
00231 }
00232 
00233 static inline void xnarch_finalize_no_switch (xnarchtcb_t *dead_tcb)
00234 
00235 {
00236     /* Empty */
00237 }
00238 
00239 static inline void xnarch_init_root_tcb (xnarchtcb_t *tcb,
00240                                          struct xnthread *thread,
00241                                          const char *name)
00242 {
00243     tcb->user_task = current;
00244     tcb->active_task = NULL;
00245     tcb->tsp = &tcb->ts;
00246 #ifdef CONFIG_XENO_HW_FPU
00247     tcb->user_fpu_owner = NULL;
00248     tcb->fpup = NULL;
00249 #endif /* CONFIG_XENO_HW_FPU */
00250     tcb->entry = NULL;
00251     tcb->cookie = NULL;
00252     tcb->self = thread;
00253     tcb->imask = 0;
00254     tcb->name = name;
00255 }
00256 
00257 asmlinkage static void xnarch_thread_trampoline (xnarchtcb_t *tcb)
00258 
00259 {
00260     rthal_local_irq_restore(!!tcb->imask);
00261     xnpod_welcome_thread(tcb->self);
00262     tcb->entry(tcb->cookie);
00263     xnpod_delete_thread(tcb->self);
00264 }
00265 
00266 static inline void xnarch_init_thread (xnarchtcb_t *tcb,
00267                                        void (*entry)(void *),
00268                                        void *cookie,
00269                                        int imask,
00270                                        struct xnthread *thread,
00271                                        char *name)
00272 {
00273     unsigned long *ksp, flags;
00274     struct pt_regs *childregs;
00275 
00276     rthal_local_irq_flags_hw(flags);
00277 
00278     ksp = (unsigned long *)((unsigned long)tcb->stackbase + tcb->stacksize - RTHAL_SWITCH_FRAME_SIZE - 4);
00279     childregs = (struct pt_regs *)ksp;
00280     memset(childregs,0,sizeof(*childregs));
00281     childregs->nip = (unsigned long)&rthal_thread_trampoline;
00282     childregs->gpr[14] = flags & ~(MSR_EE | MSR_FP);
00283     childregs->gpr[15] = (unsigned long)&xnarch_thread_trampoline;
00284     childregs->gpr[16] = (unsigned long)tcb;
00285     tcb->ts.ksp = (unsigned long)childregs - STACK_FRAME_OVERHEAD;
00286 
00287     tcb->entry = entry;
00288     tcb->cookie = cookie;
00289     tcb->self = thread;
00290     tcb->imask = imask;
00291     tcb->name = name;
00292 }
00293 
00294 /* No lazy FPU init on PPC. */
00295 #define xnarch_fpu_init_p(task) (1)
00296 
00297 static inline void xnarch_enable_fpu (xnarchtcb_t *current_tcb)
00298 
00299 {
00300 #ifdef CONFIG_XENO_HW_FPU
00301     if(!current_tcb->user_task)
00302         rthal_enable_fpu();
00303 #endif /* CONFIG_XENO_HW_FPU */
00304 }
00305 
00306 static inline void xnarch_init_fpu (xnarchtcb_t *tcb)
00307 
00308 {
00309 #ifdef CONFIG_XENO_HW_FPU
00310     /* Initialize the FPU for an emerging kernel-based RT thread. This
00311        must be run on behalf of the emerging thread. */
00312     memset(&tcb->fpuenv,0,sizeof(tcb->fpuenv));
00313     rthal_init_fpu(&tcb->fpuenv);
00314 #endif /* CONFIG_XENO_HW_FPU */
00315 }
00316 
00317 static inline void xnarch_save_fpu (xnarchtcb_t *tcb)
00318 
00319 {
00320 #ifdef CONFIG_XENO_HW_FPU
00321 
00322     if(tcb->fpup)
00323         {
00324         rthal_save_fpu(tcb->fpup);
00325 
00326         if(tcb->user_fpu_owner && tcb->user_fpu_owner->thread.regs)
00327             {
00328             tcb->user_fpu_owner_prev_msr = tcb->user_fpu_owner->thread.regs->msr;
00329             tcb->user_fpu_owner->thread.regs->msr &= ~MSR_FP;
00330             }
00331         }   
00332 
00333 #endif /* CONFIG_XENO_HW_FPU */
00334 }
00335 
00336 static inline void xnarch_restore_fpu (xnarchtcb_t *tcb)
00337 
00338 {
00339 #ifdef CONFIG_XENO_HW_FPU
00340 
00341     if(tcb->fpup)
00342         {
00343         rthal_restore_fpu(tcb->fpup);
00344 
00345         /* Note: Only enable FP in MSR, if it was enabled when we saved the
00346          * fpu state. We might have preempted Linux when it had disabled FP
00347          * for the thread, but not yet set last_task_used_math to NULL 
00348          */
00349         if(tcb->user_fpu_owner && 
00350                         tcb->user_fpu_owner->thread.regs &&
00351                         ((tcb->user_fpu_owner_prev_msr & MSR_FP) != 0))
00352             tcb->user_fpu_owner->thread.regs->msr |= MSR_FP;
00353         }   
00354 
00355     /* FIXME: We restore FPU "as it was" when Xenomai preempted Linux,
00356        whereas we could be much lazier. */
00357     if(tcb->user_task)
00358         rthal_disable_fpu();
00359 
00360 #endif /* CONFIG_XENO_HW_FPU */
00361 }
00362 
00363 #endif /* XENO_POD_MODULE */
00364 
00365 #ifdef XENO_THREAD_MODULE
00366 
00367 static inline void xnarch_init_tcb (xnarchtcb_t *tcb)
00368 {
00369     tcb->user_task = NULL;
00370     tcb->active_task = NULL;
00371     tcb->tsp = &tcb->ts;
00372     /* Note: .pgdir == NULL for a Xenomai kthread. */
00373     memset(&tcb->ts,0,sizeof(tcb->ts));
00374 #ifdef CONFIG_XENO_HW_FPU
00375     tcb->user_fpu_owner = NULL;
00376     tcb->fpup = &tcb->fpuenv;
00377 #endif /* CONFIG_XENO_HW_FPU */
00378     /* Must be followed by xnarch_init_thread(). */
00379 }
00380 
00381 #define xnarch_alloc_stack(tcb,stacksize) \
00382 ({ \
00383     int __err; \
00384     (tcb)->stacksize = stacksize; \
00385     if (stacksize == 0) { \
00386         (tcb)->stackbase = NULL; \
00387         __err = 0; \
00388     } else { \
00389         (tcb)->stackbase = xnmalloc(stacksize); \
00390         __err = (tcb)->stackbase ? 0 : -ENOMEM; \
00391     } \
00392     __err; \
00393 })
00394 
00395 #define xnarch_free_stack(tcb) \
00396 do { \
00397       if ((tcb)->stackbase) \
00398           xnfree((tcb)->stackbase); \
00399 } while(0)
00400 
00401 #endif /* XENO_THREAD_MODULE */
00402 
00403 #ifdef XENO_SHADOW_MODULE
00404 
00405 static inline void xnarch_init_shadow_tcb (xnarchtcb_t *tcb,
00406                                            struct xnthread *thread,
00407                                            const char *name)
00408 {
00409     struct task_struct *task = current;
00410 
00411     tcb->user_task = task;
00412     tcb->active_task = NULL;
00413     tcb->tsp = &task->thread;
00414 #ifdef CONFIG_XENO_HW_FPU
00415     tcb->user_fpu_owner = task;
00416     tcb->fpup = (rthal_fpenv_t *)&task->thread.fpr[0];
00417 #endif /* CONFIG_XENO_HW_FPU */
00418     tcb->entry = NULL;
00419     tcb->cookie = NULL;
00420     tcb->self = thread;
00421     tcb->imask = 0;
00422     tcb->name = name;
00423 }
00424 
00425 static inline void xnarch_grab_xirqs (void (*handler)(unsigned irq))
00426 
00427 {
00428     unsigned irq;
00429 
00430     for (irq = 0; irq < IPIPE_NR_XIRQS; irq++)
00431         rthal_virtualize_irq(rthal_current_domain,
00432                              irq,
00433                              handler,
00434                              NULL,
00435                              IPIPE_DYNAMIC_MASK);
00436 
00437     /* On this arch, the decrementer trap is not an external IRQ but
00438        it is instead mapped to a virtual IRQ, so we must grab it
00439        individually. */
00440 
00441     rthal_virtualize_irq(rthal_current_domain,
00442                          RTHAL_TIMER_IRQ,
00443                          handler,
00444                          NULL,
00445                          IPIPE_DYNAMIC_MASK);
00446 }
00447 
00448 static inline void xnarch_lock_xirqs (rthal_pipeline_stage_t *ipd, int cpuid)
00449 
00450 {
00451     unsigned irq;
00452 
00453     for (irq = 0; irq < IPIPE_NR_XIRQS; irq++)
00454         {
00455         switch (irq)
00456             {
00457 #ifdef CONFIG_SMP
00458             case RTHAL_CRITICAL_IPI:
00459 
00460                 /* Never lock out this one. */
00461                 continue;
00462 #endif /* CONFIG_SMP */
00463 
00464             default:
00465 
00466                 rthal_lock_irq(ipd,cpuid,irq);
00467             }
00468         }
00469 
00470     rthal_lock_irq(ipd,cpuid,RTHAL_TIMER_IRQ);
00471 }
00472 
00473 static inline void xnarch_unlock_xirqs (rthal_pipeline_stage_t *ipd, int cpuid)
00474 
00475 {
00476     unsigned irq;
00477 
00478     for (irq = 0; irq < IPIPE_NR_XIRQS; irq++)
00479         {
00480         switch (irq)
00481             {
00482 #ifdef CONFIG_SMP
00483             case RTHAL_CRITICAL_IPI:
00484 
00485                 continue;
00486 #endif /* CONFIG_SMP */
00487 
00488             default:
00489 
00490                 rthal_unlock_irq(ipd,irq);
00491             }
00492         }
00493 
00494     rthal_unlock_irq(ipd,RTHAL_TIMER_IRQ);
00495 }
00496 
00497 #endif /* XENO_SHADOW_MODULE */
00498 
00499 #ifdef XENO_TIMER_MODULE
00500 
00501 static inline void xnarch_program_timer_shot (unsigned long delay) {
00502     /* Even though some architectures may use a 64 bits delay here, we
00503        voluntarily limit to 32 bits, 4 billions ticks should be enough
00504        for now. Would a timer needs more, an extra call to the tick
00505        handler would simply occur after 4 billions ticks.  Since the
00506        timebase value is used to express CPU ticks on the PowerPC
00507        port, there is no need to rescale the delay value. */
00508     rthal_timer_program_shot(delay);
00509 }
00510 
00511 static inline void xnarch_stop_timer (void) {
00512     rthal_timer_release();
00513 }
00514 
00515 static inline int xnarch_send_timer_ipi (xnarch_cpumask_t mask)
00516 
00517 {
00518 #ifdef CONFIG_SMP
00519     return -1;          /* FIXME */
00520 #else /* ! CONFIG_SMP */
00521     return 0;
00522 #endif /* CONFIG_SMP */
00523 }
00524 
00525 #endif /* XENO_TIMER_MODULE */
00526 
00527 #ifdef XENO_MAIN_MODULE
00528 
00529 #include <linux/init.h>
00530 #include <nucleus/asm/calibration.h>
00531 
00532 extern u_long nkschedlat;
00533 
00534 extern u_long nktimerlat;
00535 
00536 int xnarch_escalation_virq;
00537 
00538 int xnpod_trap_fault(xnarch_fltinfo_t *fltinfo);
00539 
00540 void xnpod_schedule_handler(void);
00541 
00542 static rthal_trap_handler_t xnarch_old_trap_handler;
00543 
00544 static int xnarch_trap_fault (unsigned event, unsigned domid, void *data)
00545 {
00546     xnarch_fltinfo_t fltinfo;
00547     fltinfo.exception = event;
00548     fltinfo.regs = (struct pt_regs *)data;
00549     return xnpod_trap_fault(&fltinfo);
00550 }
00551 
00552 unsigned long xnarch_calibrate_timer (void)
00553 
00554 {
00555 #if CONFIG_XENO_HW_TIMER_LATENCY != 0
00556     return xnarch_ns_to_tsc(CONFIG_XENO_HW_TIMER_LATENCY) ?: 1;
00557 #else /* CONFIG_XENO_HW_TIMER_LATENCY unspecified. */
00558     /* Compute the time needed to program the decrementer in aperiodic
00559        mode. The return value is expressed in timebase ticks. */
00560     return xnarch_ns_to_tsc(rthal_timer_calibrate()) ?: 1;
00561 #endif /* CONFIG_XENO_HW_TIMER_LATENCY != 0 */
00562 }
00563 
00564 int xnarch_calibrate_sched (void)
00565 
00566 {
00567     nktimerlat = xnarch_calibrate_timer();
00568 
00569     if (!nktimerlat)
00570         return -ENODEV;
00571 
00572     nkschedlat = xnarch_ns_to_tsc(xnarch_get_sched_latency());
00573 
00574     return 0;
00575 }
00576 
00577 static inline int xnarch_init (void)
00578 
00579 {
00580     int err;
00581 
00582 #ifdef CONFIG_SMP
00583     /* The HAL layer also sets the same CPU affinity so that both
00584        modules keep their execution sequence on SMP boxen. */
00585     set_cpus_allowed(current,cpumask_of_cpu(0));
00586 #endif /* CONFIG_SMP */
00587 
00588     err = xnarch_calibrate_sched();
00589 
00590     if (err)
00591         return err;
00592 
00593     xnarch_escalation_virq = rthal_alloc_virq();
00594 
00595     if (xnarch_escalation_virq == 0)
00596         return -ENOSYS;
00597 
00598     rthal_virtualize_irq(&rthal_domain,
00599                          xnarch_escalation_virq,
00600                          (void (*)(unsigned))&xnpod_schedule_handler,
00601                          NULL,
00602                          IPIPE_HANDLE_MASK);
00603 
00604     xnarch_old_trap_handler = rthal_trap_catch(&xnarch_trap_fault);
00605 
00606 #ifdef CONFIG_XENO_OPT_PERVASIVE
00607     err = xnshadow_mount();
00608 #endif /* CONFIG_XENO_OPT_PERVASIVE */
00609 
00610     if (err)
00611         {
00612         rthal_trap_catch(xnarch_old_trap_handler);
00613         rthal_free_virq(xnarch_escalation_virq);
00614         }
00615 
00616     return err;
00617 }
00618 
00619 static inline void xnarch_exit (void)
00620 
00621 {
00622 #ifdef CONFIG_XENO_OPT_PERVASIVE
00623     xnshadow_cleanup();
00624 #endif /* CONFIG_XENO_OPT_PERVASIVE */
00625     rthal_trap_catch(xnarch_old_trap_handler);
00626     rthal_free_virq(xnarch_escalation_virq);
00627 }
00628
